displayed_text: Patient: Okay. So, are we, or why, are we trying these other things because - and it could be both answers - because you want to know? Or because, they’re the most effective options for me? Doctor: So. (Pause) Patient: I don’t want to compromise your ethical considerations. Doctor: So, in the realm of standard treatment, the two treatments that we have that are new hormonal treatments, we call them “Second Line Treatments.” So, the, the Lupron/Eligard is the first one. We would add a second one. Both of those have been tested in big clinical trials, and both of those showed an improvement in survival for a large group of men. It wasn’t a huge improvement. Um. But it reduced your risk of dying of prostate cancer by about thirty percent. The survival improvement was on the order of months, but that is really, uh, for the whole group. It’s hard to call the individuals outta that. Um, so that’s kind of the baseline that we know. Um. And, those drugs, you know, they have side effects that we need to manage, but that’s kind of would be the next treatment that’s standard treatment. It’s approved by the FDA because of the survival improvement. The new finding about this new drug, they’re called “PARP” inhibitors. A group did a study in England where they had fifty guys who had some DNA mutation, mostly BRCA2. They treated the fifty guys; sixteen had mutations. And, they found that none of the people without the mutations responded. Fourteen of the sixteen - so, you know, ninety percent who had a mutation responded to these drugs very well. Suggesting, they’re probably going to work really well in patients like that. Um. Patient: Am I one of those people? Doctor: Yeah, you’re one of those people. Now, that drug hasn’t been through the big paces of FDA trial approval. That’s where it is right now. So, the trials we’re looking at are looking at giving that drug alone or in combination with these standard hormones. So, the trial that I would consider for you have multiple arms. We could talk about that in detail, but, it’s there’s two different trials they could either combine the drugs or give you one drug. Um. But, the, but the, where the field is moving is there’s going to be fifty trials of this to try to nail this down. Family Member: Now, you said immuno--- Doctor: So, the other thing that’s a little further back in time Patient: But, did you say multiple “harms?” Doctor: Hormones. Patient: Hormones. Okay. Doctor: So, one of the trials is you get --

Family Member: Right. Doctor: That vaccine therapies tend to work a little better. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So with that, that’s why I think it would be a great next stop to do. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: We would have to get clearance from insurance because it’s about a hundred thousand bucks. Family Member: Whew. Doctor: Number two. It’s a limited treatment meaning you’re only going to get three infusions. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: And how it works is we take blood out of him at the Red Cross. Family Member: Right. Doctor: They send it to Atlanta to kind of wake it up.

Patient: They ain’t workin’ like they’re supposed to, doc! Doctor: There’s no way that we can get you not pooping correctly because there’s so many different types of laxatives out there – Patient: Yeah, well. Doctor: You just need to take more. Patient: Oh. Okay. Doctor: Yeah. You just don’t have enough – Patient: Enough. Doctor: On-board. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Alright. Doctor: What are you actually taking? Patient: I’m takin’ them little red ones, and it’s not –

Patient: I did. Doctor: Yeah, so it’s- Patient: Yeah, I, I, when they, they said I had phlebotomy, I asked if it was fasting, and they said “No.” So, I, uh, ate breakfast. Doctor: And your PSA today is twenty-two. Patient: Ouch. Doctor: That’s all good. And your testosterone is (pause6sec) Patient: Okay. Question. Sixteen to seventeen, and I don’t know the time frame that it went from sixteen to seventeen, but in (cell phone rings) Doctor: Yeah, don’t read much into it. You know, we’re just checking it more often. Patient: Well, I understand that, but what does that mean to the aggressiveness of the cancer? Does it - Doctor: Okay. Yeah, I mean my sense is that people who, let’s - I don’t have prostate cancer that I know of right now - but, if my PSA was going up and I don’t have the diagnosis, it sort of tells me if it’s going up that fast that I’m more likely when I put a needle in it to find bad cancer. So, we already know you’ve got bad cancer. Patient: Yeah. So, this is, doesn’t tell you. Doctor: Doesn’t tell you. Patient: Then, why do I keep getting stuck?

Family Member: The scan will detect-? Doctor: If you have the PSMA. If you have that antigen or not in your cells. Then that will help us decide whether we put you on the study or not. Patient: And you can’t get it here in the states? Doctor: Not yet. Family Member: The scan. Doctor: The scan you can get. Patient: Right. Doctor: The actual treatment, also, like I said, on the study, there’s a two out of three chance that you will get the treatment. Okay? Uh, A___? I’ll tell S___ to come in. Family Member: Oh. Okay. Doctor: But, uh, you know, I think it is a chance, and none of us have any control over what you get. But, but, at a minimum- Patient: Or- Doctor: -this is sort of the only chance we have of getting it right now.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: I’m changing all of that. Patient: Oh, you’re gonna change that? Doctor: Yes, yes. So, October fourth, you’ll just go to chemo directly, to the labs and chemo. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And, then October twenty-fifth, you’ll see me and get chemo. Patient: Okay. Okay. So, just Doctor: Okay. You need the oxycodone and the walker. Patient: And the, uh, Xanax. Doctor: What is the third script? Patient: My Xanax. That’s it here. So, I’ll need, need that, right. Doctor: Let me see when I gave you the Xanax last. (Pause)

Family Member: On some of them. I would gradually reintroduce them if I was you. Doctor: Yes. I agree with you. Patient: And I also had a question about that proton treatment that they have in B___. Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. Patient: Um Doctor: Not ah truly applicable to you at this point. That’s great for if you were just newly diagnosed with your prostate cancer or if you have some specific area on your spine. You obviously just got the radiation to there but if you know you’re a baby, for example, and you had a really tiny spinal cord, and you have this cancer next to it, a proton would be the perfect treatment. For adults, it’s a little harder to know what is better than the standard. So you know you hope maybe if you got protons you wouldn’t have had so many side effects. That’s possible. But it’s not as mainstream I think as we’d like to see it. At some point now when they’re really up and running and more patients will get experience, we’ll probably get a better sense of that. But for now I think you’ve got the best treatment which was those three areas in the spine and then your pelvis. Family Member: But is this proton more precise than-? Doctor: It’s supposed to be but I think the question is you know for the extra twenty or thirty thousand dollars that it costs- Family Member: Um Hmm. Doctor: -is that truly better than what the regulation radiation is going to afford because it’s not the old time radiation. The radiation you got is still image guided. It’s still blocked off. So those studies are ongoing. And that’s why not every center and not every state has protons. Because the cost is just astronomical- Family Member: Really. Doctor: -and not every insurance company is really paying for it. And you don’t know if it’s better. So this issue comes around a lot because of prostate. So protons wanted to replace, you know, oh, and I going to save the bladder or anything else. And that data doesn’t show it to be better necessarily. So it’s a big fight between the radiation guys. They’re trying to figure that out themselves. Um, but I don’t know. I think it’s good technology. So I think if needed, if it was a really tough spot or really small area I think it’s reasonable. But you had many spots that the radiation had to go after so I’m not sure that much of an advantage would have been gained. Patient: Well this radiation I went through this time-

Patient: I thought you were gonna say too that they weren’t’ playing nice about the the the the (stammers) Family Member: We’ve had a lot of that lately. Patient: That accompanies the injection or the… Doctor: Yes, your Neulasta is whole ‘nother whatever, I know. Patient: Because M___ had made the comment that… Doctor: Yeah another patient… Patient: …you had another patient that his insurance wouldn’t cover it until… Doctor: It’s the same thing. Patient: Okay. Okay. Doctor: Until you actually have a problem and then they go oh look he’s got a problem, okay we’ll give it to you now. I know. Patient: That’s terrible. Doctor: It’s terrible. So…

Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: and that came back as positive. So some transcripts are negative and some transcripts are positive. But that’s generally considered a positive test, which is a negative thing. Patient: Oh (chuckles) Doctor: And we tried to get your tissues set out for genetic testing, and it wasn’t enough or inadequate for them to run any tests on it. So we don’t have any more data about molecular testing. Dr. G mentions it in his note as well that that’s something that he wants to do. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So I don’t know where he is with that as to whether he’s going to try a different company or other tissue that he may have. And I don’t know what they sent. Did they send the tissue from your liver or tissue from back when you were first diagnosed? Patient: I don’t know. Doctor: I don’t know either. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: They just said it was inadequate. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So we don’t have any results about are there gene studies that you could go on. Uhm, so the ARV7 positive means that you know your cancer is pretty smart and knows how to grow despite testosterone being low, despite being on drugs like the Zytiga or the Xtandi, and that really you know as I said last time, at some point we have to decide when your cancer is worse. I tend not to rely on PSA. Patient: Mm.

Patient: Yeah, yeah, okay. Doctor: So that’s one. Normally it takes three to sometimes four doses… Patient: Okay. Doctor: …for it to work and that’s true for most medicines. It takes three to four doses of anything for anything to work. Patient: Okay. Doctor: You don’t have enough in your blood stream to do anything. Patient: Yeah, okay. Doctor: You know once we’re… Patient: Yeah. Doctor: The good news is when I see this though it tells me it will die. Patient: Sure. Doctor: Because sometimes we give the chemo and it just keeps on going and you’re like what happened? Didn’t I just poison you?

Patient: Oh. Doctor: And so, this study is looking at a new therapy –uh, the hottest new drugs that are out there, and when we’ve given them to men with prostate cancer, we haven’t seen a whole lot. (Pause) Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: Um. And the two drugs together, uh, may be, uh, cause responses. Uh, but we don’t know. And that’s why we’re doing a research study. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And we’re giving folks who’ve got bad disease this because the worry is these drugs may have a lot of side effects. Most of the time, they’re tolerated well, but what they do is they turn on your immune system, hope that your immune system is going to attack your cancer, but I also could turn on your immune system with these medicines and it attacks you. Okay? So you can get a pneumonia that’s from your immune system. You can get hepatitis because it’s attacking your liver. You could get colitis ‘cuz it’s attacking your colon. Uh, it usually picks one organ, not not all of ‘em, but, you know, you can get into trouble because your immune system – while it’s tryin’ to fight your cancer, it’s tryin’ to fight you. Uh. And when we Patient: I see. This is from the – both the uh– the, uh, both of the – Doctor: Both ipilimumab and nivolumab. Patient: Okay. (laughs) Doctor: Big words. Patient: Who makes these things up? Doctor: They don’t want us to use -- they want us to use a Yervoy and Opdivo – the shorter ones, but they have big names so if we don’t use them – but I have to use ‘em. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Okay, because when I went there they said they didn’t see it. Doctor: Okay. Patient: And I had to call in and they faxed it. Doctor: Okay. I will do two things today. When I place the prescription I will send electronically and then I will also print the actual paper prescription. Patient: Okay. Uh huh. Doctor: And hand it to you. That should be the backup. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: In a perfect world, I should be able to print that so that you don’t have to go through that. Patient: That’s okay. Doctor: I can place it for - over the - Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So uh we’ll place an order.

Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: The reason is so you know everybody wants to be helpful and you know give you all kinds of natural products and things like mistletoe or kabuki mushrooms or whatever. The problem is that a lot of them are antioxidants. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So they’re really good stuff, except when you’re trying to kill bad things, and then they interfere because one of the things we’re trying to do in chemo is make reactive oxygen species which kill, make the DNA not work and breaks up and then the cells break up. If you give a medicine like mistletoe to interfere with the creation of those uh you know, what’s basically hydrogen peroxide that kills ah the cells, then you’re interfering with chemotherapy and radiation therapies. Family Member: The effectiveness of the chemo Patient: So that would be something . Uh nutrition – Then I’m scheduled to speak with someone from a company out of Colorado called Doctor: Hmmmm Patient: Should I hold off on that during the period of treatment as well? Doctor: So, so, yes. Uhm um they have some things that interfere with what we do. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And so I’m you know all holistic approaches for all these things. I can tell you back in the day I wrote books about this stuff. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Okay but what I do in the meantime (laughs) Doctor: Well that’s why I was saying that well if there was somebody else with you, I’m concerned that you’re going to take both and it will be too much, it will zonk you out. Okay there’s nobody here with you even to tell for me to tell and the dangerous thing is you have your Ambiens at home. Patient: Right. Doctor: So you very well could make a mistake and take both, take the Ambien and the new sleeping pill. Patient: No I wouldn’t take the Ambien then. I’ll just throw them out. Doctor: You sure? Patient: Yeah I will pull them out. Doctor: You’ll remember to do that?
PAT Yes, yes I will. Okay. Patient: Yes I will. I would so like it now I would take them Ambiens that I got, I will pull them out. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Yeah I’ll dispose, how do we say it, dispose of them. Doctor: Now you’re gonna remember to do that? Patient: Yes I am, yes I am.

Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: …is that this is all related to the prostate cancer. So um I don’t think there’s any reason for me to believe or doubt that this is gonna be the prostate cancer. It’s theoretically possible it could be a gist. All right. I think it’s extremely, extremely unlikely. Patient: And how would we know? I knew your recommendation was that since it’s a low level in in the lymph node… Doctor: Yeah. Patient: - um that it’s something you wouldn’t biopsy, but um I guess - Doctor: The best way to find out in my opinion – Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: - is open for discussion is to treat this as if it was a prostate cancer and see if it goes away. Patient: Okay, so - Doctor: And if it does, and in retrospect, because if we give you a hormone therapy, for example and it’s a gist, it will not increase sized at all. Patient: Correct. Doctor: If it’s a hormone therapy and it’s prostate cancer, you know it’s gonna disappear or decrease by ninety percent within the first few months. Patient: Okay, would that be your recommendation, to do more hormonal?

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.4 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::4 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.disagree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::disagree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.disagree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::disagree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.disagree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::disagree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::agree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.Some college: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Some college

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Black or African American: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Black or African American
